title: Sort option: sort alphabetically
body:
Please implement a sort option to sort tasks (**especially completed tasks**) alphabetically.
Use case: **Mirakel Shopping List**
A shopping list has _items_ as tasks (e.g. milk, bread, lettuce, etc.) to be ticked off. When a shopping list is being made, previously completed items can be "un-completed" to add them back to the list. It should be quick and easy to find those items. Sorting completed items by creation date or completion date does **not** make it easy to find a single item in a list of ~100 items. Sorting alphabetically by task name **would** make it easy, greatly enhancing Mirakel's flexibility as a _list manager_.
Perhaps the sort by "Alphabetical" option could replace the redundant "Default" option (which appears to be the exact same as "Created date"?)

> This would be very useful. In Astrid, they were very smart about providing smart reminders based on what most needed to be done. If you also added a scheduled start date, you could then have Mirakel provide smart reminders (and congratulations) too, eg if:
> 
> TTC = Time user set to complete the task, eg due date/time minus start date/time
> TSS = Time since task was scheduled to start
> PCD = Percent the task is done (0-1)
> PRI = Priotity set by the user

title: Mirakel 3 UI Design
label: [Label(name="UI"), Label(name="enhancement")]
body:
Hello everyone,
I have the honor to redesign the user interface of the coming Mirakel 3. The interface will be designed for the new Andriod L. Therefore I did some early drafts, which are attached here. Now we want to hear your thoughts about this!
Every kind of feedback is welcome. Just comment what you like and don't like, what you would change or what you miss here. And if you have a question about the UI, animations or what else…just ask us!

Before you start, keep in mind that everything is a subject of change. **Nothing is final!** It's just a draft how it could be. And yes, a tablet version is also coming, don't worry! :wink:

:one: 
The whole interface is now cleaned up to focus more on the content. The task cards and the app bar just contain the most important things to see at the first look.
![Start View - Default List](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596368/ed6241f4-0cc3-11e4-871b-20ac7f606094.png)

Cause Mirakel has tons of features we need a more button in the app bar. Here you can access everything else. The Menu will later contain tiny icons to spot the content even faster, but first we should be clear what the menu contains.
![Start View - More Menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596370/fdb89c24-0cc3-11e4-96b5-73dc02a8c68f.png)

:two: 
The task lists are now separated into the fixed lists (on top) and the account/user lists (bottom), which change if you switch the account. This is possible via the app bar. If you touch the title you are able to select an account (local, cloud, …) and of course add a new one.
![Task Lists](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596374/05ba7dfc-0cc4-11e4-8dfe-a34f59267881.png)

:three: 
Touching a task causes the editing mode. The card gets the focus and grows with a smooth animation. The card now shows only the filled data. To add more data you have to touch the "add more button".
![Edit task](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596376/0778c40a-0cc4-11e4-9ead-14a5bc2c9581.png)

:four: 
Pressing the green floating "+" button causes a nice animation and adds a new task card to the list. The keyboard will be instantly shown, so you just can start typing. Pressing "next" jumps trough the textfields.
![Add Task](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596377/0f675398-0cc4-11e4-995a-a79b1d205880.png)
![Add Task 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596379/1275db5e-0cc4-11e4-9594-eb3fda1cf15b.png)
![Add Task 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596381/176a6e68-0cc4-11e4-817d-8171aa844bf3.png)

This is how the add task animation could looks like.
![mirakel animation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596583/e0749b92-0cc6-11e4-96af-c64bb16fa57c.gif)

:five: 
The search field animates now into the app bar.
![Search](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6615076/3596383/19120a32-0cc4-11e4-9bef-b7de09a012f1.png)

- Last sync key is saved in the android account manager
### Should-state
- Certificates are saved in the android account manager
- Lists and tasks are saved in the database
- Credentials and Account settings are saved in the android account manager
- Last sync key is saved in the database
### Why?
- If you clear the app data the accounts are not deleted but the certificates
- If you import the database in a fresh install there are no accounts available but there are „old“ tasks. If you now sync with taskwarrior (after creating a new account) it looks for a sync key – but you did not have one. Because the uuids of the tasks are the same taskwarrior get confused and abort the sync with the message that no common ancestor was found.

> This would be very useful. In Astrid, they were very smart about providing smart reminders based on what most needed to be done. If you also added a scheduled start date, you could then have Mirakel provide smart reminders (and congratulations) too, eg if:
> 
> TTC = Time user set to complete the task, eg due date/time minus start date/time
> TSS = Time since task was scheduled to start
> PCD = Percent the task is done (0-1)
> PRI = Priotity set by the user
> 
> Then after the start date, you can figure out whether a tasks progress is behind schedule based on whether PRG is <1 where:
> PRG = PCD / (TSS/TTC)
> 
> So 0-1 is behind schedule. 2 would be that they're going twice the scheduled speed, etc. A relative scale of how much attention the user should give to each task to finish on time (ATT) would then be:
> ATT = (1-PRG)*PRI
> 
> I would LOVE to be able to list tasks by what I should give attention to. It would make life so easy to be able to just look at the task list and know that whatever was up the top, was the task to work on now (making sure that I updated the progress of the task regularly, of course).
